name: Software Development and Design Suite
description: This parent feature encompasses packages and tools necessary for software development, graphical application development, and professional design work across a variety of platforms and frameworks. It includes support for design-focused tools, development libraries, and specialized frameworks for building applications in GNOME, KDE, Xfce, LibreOffice, and the X Window System. Additionally, it covers legacy font packages essential for maintaining compatibility with older design assets and workflows.

name: Enterprise Infrastructure Services
description: A comprehensive suite of tools, frameworks, and systems designed to provide a robust foundation for managing, maintaining, and enhancing enterprise-level IT infrastructure. This feature encompasses functionalities for backup solutions, identity and directory management, high availability configurations, load balancing, database management, network services, and security mechanisms. It equips organizations with everything needed to ensure seamless operations, centralized management, and resilient infrastructure capabilities.

name: Desktop Environment Applications and Support
description: A comprehensive set of applications, office suites, multimedia tools, and extensions tailored to enhance functionality and support across various Linux desktop environments. This feature includes support for KDE, LXQt, Xfce, LXDE, Deepin, and other key ecosystems, offering productivity, multimedia, and desktop-specific utilities to ensure a cohesive user experience. It provides everything from personal information management tools to office suites, multimedia frameworks, translations, and plugin extensions, covering the diverse needs of users across various desktop environments.
children: Extra plugins for the Xfce panel

name: Development and Compatibility Platforms
description: A comprehensive set of development tools, programming language support, compatibility libraries, and runtime platforms to facilitate open-source application development, legacy application compatibility, and modern web and enterprise application deployment on Linux. This parent feature aggregates resources for developers to build, run, and deploy software across diverse environments and programming ecosystems effectively.

name: System Tools and Utilities
description: A comprehensive set of tools and utilities designed to facilitate system management, debugging, performance monitoring, network configuration, hardware simulation, and security auditing. This parent feature encompasses a wide variety of functionalities to support system administrators, hardware engineers, and developers in effectively building, managing, and troubleshooting systems of all sizes and complexities. It integrates both command-line and graphical utilities to provide flexibility in addressing diverse use cases.

name: Graphical Desktop Environments and Window Managers
description: This feature covers a comprehensive collection of graphical desktop environments, window managers, and associated applications for Linux systems. It includes both traditional desktops with user-friendly interfaces and lightweight options for systems with lower hardware specifications. The feature provides support for various desktop paradigms including tiling window managers, traditional desktops, and modern user experiences. It also includes supplemental applications, games, and utilities tailored to enhance each environment's capabilities. Additionally, packages for compatibility with legacy X Window systems and essential session components are provided, ensuring broad usability and integration across various setups.
children: Extra games for the GNOME Desktop

name: Linux System Product Core and Conflicts Management
description: This feature represents the core functionality and conflict management for various Linux system products, including Atomic Host, Linux Client, ComputeNode, Server, and Workstation variants. It includes required packages to support ostree functionality, core product requirements, and handles package conflicts for each product type, as well as repositories like AppStream and BaseOS. Additionally, it incorporates graphical enhancements and support for package installation variations to ensure compatibility and optimized deployment across different Linux environments.

name: Development and Creative Tools Suite
description: A comprehensive suite of development, scientific, and creative tools designed to support a wide array of workflows, from software development and packaging to scientific research, graphics design, and audio production. This feature encompasses specialized toolsets for programming, data science, and artistic endeavors, making it an all-encompassing resource for professionals in diverse domains.

name: Cloud and Virtualization Ecosystem
description: Provides a comprehensive suite of tools, utilities, and packages designed for managing and operationalizing cloud computing environments, containerized applications, virtualization platforms, and hypervisors. This feature encompasses solutions for cloud infrastructure management, virtualization support for different platforms, container orchestration, and tools for server and guest management across various environments. It integrates technologies to facilitate seamless interaction with cloud and virtualized ecosystems, making it ideal for developers, IT administrators, and enterprises.

name: Comprehensive System and Application Support
description: This parent feature encompasses a broad set of tools, utilities, and packages designed to support various system configurations, application needs, hardware functionalities, and user environments. It includes features for system administration, software development, network management, database services, accessibility, graphics, engineering tools, internet applications, server configurations, text-based utilities, and compatibility with legacy and modern systems. The goal is to provide a modular and extensible framework for creating a fully functional and versatile system setup, accommodating diverse user requirements and operational scenarios.

name: System Service and Application Hosting
description: A comprehensive parent feature encompassing diverse software tools, system services, and hosting capabilities that enable the system to perform critical network, printing, storage, web, and application server functions. This includes functionalities for communication, data storage, file sharing, software hosting, and system management, ensuring robust and versatile operational capabilities.

name: Content Creation and Educational Tools
description: A comprehensive suite of tools and utilities designed to facilitate content creation, technical documentation, educational activities, and language-specific text rendering. This feature includes support for authoring and publishing documents, writing and editing text, educational software for learning, font rendering for multilingual text, advanced input methods, Python learning tools, dedicated desktop environments for education, and technical systems for formatting and editing such as TeX.

name: Linux Installation and Critical Path Features
description: This feature encapsulates the essential components and workflows necessary for the installation, core functionality, and critical path operations of a Linux distribution. It includes the base installation, minimal setups, and comprehensive collections of packages and utilities tailored for both desktop environments and server configurations. Additionally, it covers Critical Path groupings that ensure shared functionality and platform consistency across different Linux spins, environments, and use cases such as application building, composing deliverables, and targeted setups like desktop environments (GNOME, KDE, Xfce, and others), robotics development, and server editions. The KDE Spin Initial Setup and utilities for extensions to the minimal installation (Standard utilities) are also encompassed within this feature.
